segments.text: One, two, three, four, testing.
Murray, now you say something.
Hello, hello, I'm here.
This is September the 12th, and I have the pleasure and honor of chatting with the postdoctoral role
while I join the faculty at Cornell.
Dr. Morris Bloodworth, who was head of the department at Texas A&M during those years
and who had served on my master's committee,
had told me at many professional meetings that it was just a matter of time
until he would recruit me back to Texas A&M for faculty.
So after I'd been at Cornell five years, Dr. Bloodworth came along with a faculty offer.
By that time, I'd developed quite a good feel for Cornell.
Really was uncertain about whether I would be granted tenure there or not
and knew if I was not going to receive tenure, the decision would be a very easy one.
But if I actually served on the Cornell faculty as an associate professor for two months,
I'd have to go back to Texas A&M.
That was probably the hardest professional decision I've ever made.
You can look back even to this day and wonder, I guess, in some respects,
whether it was the right decision or not.
A lot of things played into it.
We were about 1,800 miles from my family,
and we were 1,000 miles from my wife's family,
and they were 1,000 miles apart.
And that made any kind of, well, it took all the vacation.
We had in the summer in those days with young children to,
we'd spend three weeks vacation and we'd spend about half of it on the road.
And so that was a strong motivating factor.
I did not know whether my wife, who was a native of Wisconsin,
whom I met during my Ph.D. years,
more familiar with the soil than the state,
and to interact with Dr. Dixon, who preceded me here by about two months.
So we had the same kind...
We had the same kinds of research interests.
Well, it really...
And then Chambers County, I remember, down on the Gulf Coast,
and those were all one-week stays and seen very extensively.
Those would come during what we call a final field review
for the survey of those counties, the soil survey.
So you go to all the parts of the county and you see the major kinds of soils
that occur in that environment and discuss all of the different controversies
about how to classify them.
So you go to all the parts of the county and you see the major kinds of soils that occur in that environment and discuss all of the different controversies about how to classify them.
and their uses and limitations and that kind of thing.
That was an extremely fortunate to have that luxury and time,
I suppose you'd say, in the first year.
But to this day, I use a lot of slides in teaching the introductory soils course
that I got in that first nine months I was here.
And not to mention just the knowledge and appreciation for the variety of soils in the state.
What else did you learn
about the people of Texas and their variety from those weeks?
Well, I don't know if, of course, I grew up in Texas,
and since I went to A&M, I guess you could say I had classmates from all parts of the state.
One of the things when I first began teaching that truly shocked me
was the variety in terms of origin of surnames of students I had in class in Texas
as compared to New York State.
If you'd asked me offhand,
I would have said there would have been a lot greater cultural diversity
in the student body at Cornell University than there would be at Texas A&M.
That's not the case.
There's a much, I immediately encountered so many different from all over Eastern Europe
and Germany and those, not to mention the Hispanic influence here as compared to New York.
So, about the only thing you could say
is that at Cornell, in contrast, would be a much greater Jewish presence
among the students at Cornell than here.
I didn't recognize, at that time, I wouldn't have recognized a Jewish surname from any other name,
but I had a lab technician who was quite good at it and had some prejudices,
so he didn't hesitate to express his feelings about some.
Incidentally, the Jewish students at Cornell
were outstanding students in the classroom, exceptional students.
Describe your getting settled into the department.
Where was it, about how many people,
who were the key leaders of the department in 1968?
That became head in 1963 and continued in that role until 1979,
so he was obviously the kingpin in the department at that time.
Actually, the department probably
had more graduate students at that time than it has today.
The faculty was not as large, although it,
Dr. Bloodworth hired his first faculty member, I believe, in 1964 or five.
And in 1968, counting faculty here and off campus,
I believe there were five or six employees in that year alone.
And then continuing through the mid-'70s,
there was a considerable addition to the faculty
in terms of breadth of expertise in soil science as well as other disciplines.
So that was a period, well, a period for the entire university,
but it was a period of very rapid growth for the department,
and I think that was primarily his leadership.
I think almost anybody, even today here,
would tell you that Morris Bloodworth and, as I mentioned, O.D.
and maybe Perry,
they've got the lion's share of the increases
that were enjoyed during those early years.
George Kunze had already moved to the graduate college when I got here.
Jack Ruckles was soon to become director of Water Resources Institute,
so Jack would have been a leader,
but gosh, there were a number of other faculty members.
About how many total?
On campus, probably,
and this is a wild guess, I don't know, probably 30, I'm guessing, 30.
What do you think the national reputation of the department was then?
Not very good.
I think you could generally say that for most,
but by that time, by that time, recognized as an up-and-coming place.
Because we'd already, by that time, just beginning to see really the takeoff
that stemmed from all the,
all the decisions that Dr.
Rudder was instrumental in making and bringing to fruition.
So the enrollment was definitely on the upswing,
beginning to hire faculty,
having a lot of retirements of some people who had done,
had performed yeoman service,
but of an entirely different type than faculty to give you any kind of national presence would give.
Where were you all located and what were your facilities?
Well, the department's always been in several buildings.
As large a facility as we have now, you'd think we'd all be in one building, but we aren't.
At that time, I was housed in what is now the Butler Building.
It was known then as the Gromby Building.
And the building next to it, we referred to as the old red brick building,
and most of the soils faculty were in that building.
Now, that's over near the system?
Yeah.
The Butler Building is the, is kind of across from the old physics building and the trigon,
the old theory science building.
The one with the big columns in front, you look down at the MSD area,
you look right into the Gromby Building.
And the old red brick building, it's no longer red, but it still stands,
was immediately next to that one on the northwest side.
So it would be, in a sense, further up the street toward the Cushing Library at that time.
So we occupied primarily those two buildings.
Shared the state chemist at that time was in the old red brick building.
In fact, it was called the state chemist building.
But a lot of the soils faculty were in there.
It was a, it was a dungeon.
No air conditioning, no central air in any of those buildings at that time.
All window air conditioning.
Where were the labs that you and other, and your colleagues used for your instruction?
Well, the lab that I used was on the first,
in the kind of basement, half basement in the old Gromby Building.
I mean, it had windows, but it was mostly below ground, half and half.
The man who had been teaching in that position had, well, it really wasn't his first love.
He'd taught a senior level course before teaching that.
He was known for being reasonably cantankerous.
And then there was a fellow that preceded him,
his nickname was Whiskey Jack.
Guys used to talk about finding him inebriated on lab benches at times.
I would say that basic soils course, which is very important in the entire agricultural activity,
it needed, it needed some attention.
And the lab was, oh, it was in pitiful shape.
And my predecessor was in it through the fall and spring of 1968-69.
And my first teacher,
my second teacher was in the summer of 1969.
So I had, I couldn't, I didn't have any access to the facility until he was gone.
I think it's fair to say I've never worked harder in my life than I worked that summer.
As you, during that first year, what kind of advice did anyone give you
about being a faculty member here or anything like that?
Did anybody give you any guidelines or rules or?
No, you know, I don't remember being given a lot of advice.
I guess I probably got as much advice from Dean Kunkle as anybody,
although I didn't spend a lot of time with Dean Kunkle.
But he was always philosophized with you a little bit.
Dr. Potts, of course, was an institution at that time in the College of Agriculture as Associate Dean.
And I'll have to give, I'll have to give him a lot of credit in this sense.
In those first two or three years, he encouraged me to go to regional teaching workshops.
And anything that came up that I think he thought would be any kind of help or guidance in teaching,
he was very eager to encourage you to take part in it.
Dr. Bloodworth would always support him, but he'd never think about having somebody look.
For those kinds of opportunities, Dr. Potts did.
And so he had a major role in getting me out to learn about developments
in the technological aspect of the teaching at that time.
And was extremely supportive.
Within the department, actually the man I followed had been the graduate advisor for the department.
And in addition to teaching the undergraduate course, I almost inherited that role.
And that meant almost from day one, while I didn't have graduate students myself,
other than some, well, I did have a few, but very few along.
But basically, I interacted with all of the faculty in that role as graduate advisor.
So I had a lot of opportunity to interact with other faculty members across a pretty,
I mean our department represents a wide variety of disciplines.
So I had an opportunity to interact with a lot of people that I wouldn't have otherwise.
What was it, now you were a former student from this department.
Did that turn out to be an advantage, a disadvantage, or a mixed blessing as you were a young, new faculty member?
It was obviously an advantage in getting a job in the first place.
I don't think it had anything to do, most...
None of the veterans came in to talk down to you or anything?
No, no.
A lot of them, so many of us were at the same time.
What did you and your colleagues think were the unspoken, unwritten guidelines about when you went to work,
what you wore, how you did your job?
What did you assume were the guidelines for you as a professional?
Well, I expect most of us thought we ought to be at work at 8 o'clock in the morning,
we ought to stay there till 5, and obviously all of us were 12 month employees.
So we thought unless it was a holiday or we were on vacation, we should be there.
And how did you...
Now the dress was, I think most of us always wore a tie when we were going to the classroom.
But a lot of the work of faculty in the department has always been field oriented.
So I think it's always been acceptable, if you were not in the classroom, to dress casually.
And you're, beginning in 69, what were your responsibilities for courses and so forth in the early years?
What courses were you to teach?
Oh, well, you know, this is, but pretty much throughout my entire career,
my major responsibility in teaching has been one course.
It's been the introductory course in soil science.
What number?
Agronomy 301.
Did it have a nickname among the students?
Well, I've heard it referred to as Murray Milford's Magical Mystery Hour.
Okay, okay.
Some of the students went out one year and bought t-shirts and came back in with them on.
They had Milford's clods on the back of their t-shirts.
And this is normally to juniors?
It's a junior level course.
Okay.
But it's taken by anything from sophomores to graduate students.
And probably most of those, most of the years I've taught it, it's been maybe more juniors than anything else.
But next to that, seniors.
And it almost ranged all the way from, I guess, when I first started, around 100 students a semester.
We've always taught it fall, spring, and summer.
I have not.
I've not missed since, well, since the summer of 69, I've not missed a summer, fall, or spring to teach that course.
Now, when enrollment, the enrollment went as high as 426.
And I had them all that semester.
Shortly thereafter, we were able to add some faculty.
So there have been a couple of other people who have taught the course.
And this is the basic course for anyone majoring in soil and crop sciences.
And what else?
It's been a required course.
Of course, it's required for all the students that are a major.
But it's been a required course in many other disciplines over the years.
Not as many today as in the past.
But when I came here, it was required for all students in animal science, recreation parks,
horticulture, agricultural education, range land ecology and management.
It would have been range science back then.
Plant science is strongly recommended in a couple of areas in ag economics.
Wildlife and fisheries required in part of their programs.
Always had some students from geology.
Some study in earth science for teaching purposes.
No engineers, no M.E.s.
No agricultural engineering was required in ag engineering.
Oh, okay.
What were, as you started out in that course, what were your private guidelines for how you were hoping to do the course?
For you as a teacher, what was your philosophy?
I really don't know all the things that shaped how I put the course together.
I suppose you could say I was strongly influenced by what I found at Cornell when I began teaching there.
The textbook used for the course there was, at that time, called Buckman and Brady.
It goes back into, the textbook is now in its 12th edition, I believe.
It goes back into the 1920s, probably.
And Dr. Brady was the department head, actually.
He moved to the department head when I became a member of the faculty.
But we alternated teaching that course there.
One fellow taught it in the fall.
I taught it in the spring.
And then we alternated in the summer to teach it.
And this fellow had more experience with that course than I did.
But we met together every summer and went over the content of the laboratory.
He has a laboratory with him.
So he, in effect, re-did the laboratory exercises every summer.
And so I had a chance to make inputs into those.
So I guess the content was pretty much shaped to that.
Although the fellow that I took introductory soils from at Texas A&M was a man named Hank Foth.
F-O-T-H. F-O-T-H.
He was only at Texas A&M three years when he went to Michigan State, which I believe was his alma mater.
He spent the rest of his career there.
He gave, I thought he was an excellent teacher.
Subsequently, I think, Michigan State proved that.
He wrote a textbook as well.
His textbook, I got a lot of ideas from.
But it was not nearly as old, meaty is probably the right term, as the one that we had at Cornell.
So I used, but I took ideas from it.
And that's how we developed the course.
And I would say that it's not, as far as the organization and topics treated, it's not changed substantially over the years.
With the big emphasis on behavioral objectives or instructional objectives, it was beginning to be a big deal in the late 60s and early 70s.
I totally did instructional objectives, which I had not done before.
Somewhere early on.
And I, do you know, right now, I'm not at all sure whether I started doing it at Cornell or not.
But I think maybe I did.
Remember, I was on the faculty there from 1963 to 1968.
It was during a period, Vietnam, during a period where I think faculty became very hesitant to say anything controversial to students.
You weren't supposed to.
I, I'm not, and I'm not honestly not sure.
I'm not sure when I started doing it.
But I started early on to think that in addition to trying to teach subject matter, cognitive and subject matter,
the faculty member had about as much responsibility to try to be a witness to life, philosophize a little bit about life and what it's all about.
So I would always editorialize.
And when I started doing this, I'm not sure, but I did it at Cornell.
I know the idea for doing it was developed there, and I think I probably did.
So I always tell my classes the first five minutes are mine.
We talk about whatever we want to.
You know, this semester I've already talked about bonfire.
I've talked about credit cards and their use.
I've talked about alcohol.
I've talked about silver tabs being an important tradition, urging to participate.
I've talked about being environmentally aware.
Take trash out of the classroom.
Close doors behind you when you go in and out of bed.
So I've done that kind of thing.
All, all.
Yeah, and I have a, I have a final editorial that runs about 25 minutes, which is,
that's the only time that I make any overt statement about being a Christian, but I do in that final 25 minutes of class.
What's been the reaction, you think, over the years?
I don't have any comments about the editorials on the course critique questionnaire and anything else.
I guess we'll get somewhere between two and five comments in the vein of,
I'll pay my money to take soil science, I don't care to hear your philosophy.
I've never been bothered by those because I feel like at least once or twice I've pricked them in a pretty sensitive spot.
Did you have, in all of your teaching, did you have any role models
that affected the way you did it?
Probably my mother and dad.
Okay.
Bigger role models than anybody.
I come from a family of teachers.
My mother was a teacher.
Her sisters were teachers.
Her brother was a teacher.
So there were four of them.
They were all teachers.
